description: Designed to decrypt files encrypted by 777 Ransom.
Trend Micro Ransomware Decryptor is designed to decrypt files encrypted by 777 Ransom.
detailed_description:
Trend Micro Ransomware File Decryptor User Guide

1. General Information

This tool is provided by Trend Micro to attempt recovery of files encrypted by certain types of ransomware. There is no guarantee of successful decryption for every ransomware variant; in some cases, only partial recovery may be possible.

The most effective protection against ransomware includes:
	•	Performing regular backups
	•	Keeping the operating system and applications up to date
	•	Using an up-to-date security solution

⸻

2. Supported Ransomware Types

The tool supports CryptXXX (V1–V5), TeslaCrypt (V1–V4), CERBER V1, Locky, Jigsaw, Nemucod, Chimera, XORIST, BadBlock, and several other ransomware families listed in the documentation.
Note: For TeslaCrypt V1 and V2, it may be necessary to contact Trend Micro Technical Support separately.

⸻

3. Downloading and Running the Tool
	1.	Download the Trend Micro Ransomware File Decryptor from the official Trend Micro website.
	2.	Extract the ZIP file.
	3.	Run the RansomwareFileDecryptor.exe file.
	4.	Accept the End User License Agreement (EULA).

⸻

4. Step-by-Step Usage

Step 1: Select the Ransomware Type
	•	If you know the ransomware type from the ransom note left on the system, select it from the list.
	•	If you are unsure, you can select the “I don’t know the ransomware name” option. In this case, the tool will attempt to automatically identify the ransomware based on the file signature.

Step 2: Select the Encrypted File or Folder
	•	You can select a single file or an entire folder (including subfolders).
	•	Click the “Select & Decrypt” button to make your selection.

Step 3: Start the Decryption Process
	•	The tool will automatically begin scanning and decrypting files.
	•	The duration of the process may vary depending on the number of files and the ransomware type.
	•	If needed, the process can be stopped by clicking the “Stop” button.

Step 4: Cases Requiring Additional Information (Optional)
	•	For certain ransomware types such as CryptXXX V1, XORIST, XORBAT, or Nemucod, the tool may request additional information.
	•	In this case:
	•	Select an encrypted file
	•	Select the same file in its unencrypted form (from a backup, if available)
	•	Larger file sizes are preferred

Step 5: Completing the Process
	•	Once the process is completed, the results screen will be displayed.
	•	By selecting “See encrypted files,” the folder containing the files will be opened.
	•	Decrypted files will be located in the same folder.
	•	Click “Done” to return to the main screen.

⸻

5. Important Notes
	•	For CryptXXX V3, it may not be possible to fully recover all files.
	•	If files were encrypted without changing their original names, decrypted files will be saved with a “decrypted” suffix.
	•	Successful decryption is not guaranteed for every file.

description: Designed to decrypt files encrypted by AES_NI Ransom.
Designed to decrypt files encrypted by AES_NI Ransom.
RakhniDecryptor is a tool provided by Kaspersky to decrypt files encrypted by Trojan-Ransom.Win32.Rakhni.
detailed_description:
RakhniDecryptor is a tool provided by Kaspersky to decrypt files encrypted by Trojan-Ransom.Win32.Rakhni.

Before using the tool, the ransomware must be completely removed from the system. Otherwise, files may be re-encrypted during or after the decryption process.

The ransomware creates a file named exit.hhr.oshit, which contains encrypted password data required for faster decryption.
If this file is still present on the system, decryption will be quicker. If it was deleted, it can be recovered using file recovery tools and placed back into the %APPDATA% directory.

Supported Encrypted File Extensions
	•	.locked
	•	.kraken
	•	.darkness

Decryption Process (High Level)
	1.	Download and run RakhniDecryptor.exe on the infected system.
	2.	Configure scan parameters (hard drives, removable drives, network drives).
	3.	Start the scan and select one encrypted file when prompted.
	4.	The tool attempts to recover the encryption password and decrypt files.

Important Notes
	•	Password recovery may take a long time (up to several days).
	•	The system should not be shut down and the tool should not be closed during decryption.
	•	Successful decryption is not guaranteed for all files and depends on file integrity and available data.

description: AES_NI Decryptor is designed to decrypt files encrypted by AES_NI Ransom.
detailed_description:
Avast Ransomware Decryption Tools are standalone utilities designed to decrypt files encrypted by specific ransomware families (for example: Globe). Each ransomware family requires its own dedicated decryptor executable.

Before starting the decryption process, it is strongly recommended to ensure that the ransomware malware has been fully removed from the system.

⸻

Decryption Process (High Level)
	1.	Download the appropriate decryptor file (for example: avast_decryptor_globe.exe) and run it.
	2.	If Windows SmartScreen appears, select More info and then Run anyway.
	3.	Follow the wizard and select the files, folders, or drives to decrypt.
	4.	If required, provide:
	•	One encrypted file
	•	The same file in its original, unencrypted form (from a backup or trusted source)
	5.	If password cracking is needed, the tool will attempt to recover the encryption password.
	6.	Start the decryption process and wait until completion.

⸻

Supported File Extensions

Supported extensions depend on the specific ransomware family targeted by the decryptor. The extensions are typically ransomware-added suffixes (for example, Globe variants such as .decrypt2017), not original file types.

⸻

Important Notes
	•	Password cracking may consume significant system resources and take a long time.
	•	The original and encrypted versions of a file may be required for successful decryption.
	•	Running the decryptor with administrator privileges is recommended.
	•	Successful decryption is not guaranteed for all files and depends on ransomware variant and file integrity.
	•	Backing up encrypted files before decryption is strongly advised.

Decryptor for Al-Namrood ransomware, a fork of Apocalypse that targets servers with RDP enabled. Encrypted files renamed to *.unavailable or *.disappeared.
notes: Requires the ID from the ransom note. Run decryptor on the same system where encryption occurred.

description: Decryptor for Apocalypse ransomware. Files encrypted with extensions like .encrypted, .FuckYourData, .Encryptedfile, .SecureCrypted.
notes: Ransom notes named How_To_Decrypt.txt or similar.

description: Decryptor for ApocalypseVM variant. Requires an encrypted file of at least 4096 bytes and its unencrypted version.
notes: Drag and drop both encrypted and unencrypted file onto the decrypter executable.

description: Decryptor for CheckMail7 ransomware that appends the extension [checkmail7@protonmail.com].
Decryptor for RedRum ransomware which encrypts files using AES256 GCM and RSA-1024. Also works for Thanos variant.
notes: Also decrypts files with .thanos extension.

description: Decryptor for SpartCrypt ransomware using AES-128. Also works for CoronaCrypt variant.
notes: Works for both SpartCrypt and CoronaCrypt variants.

description: Decryptor for Stampado ransomware kit. Written in AutoIt, encrypts files using AES-256 and renames to *.locked.
notes: Requires email address and ID from ransom note. Both are case-sensitive. Each infection has a unique salt.

description: Decryptor for STOP Puma ransomware variant. Appends .puma, .pumas, .pumax, .INFOWAIT or .DATAWAIT extensions.
Decryptor for Yashma ransomware (also known as AstraLocker 2.0). Based on Chaos ransomware builder, uses AES-128 and RSA-2048.
notes: Distributed as 'AstraLocker 2.0'. May have random 4-character extension.

description: Decryptor for CrypBoss, HydraCrypt and UmbreCrypt ransomware families.
